title: Righteous
description: The first posthumous single put out by his estate, “Righteous” is an emotional ballad for Juice WRLD fans. Featuring Juice’s usual topics of drugs and glamour with fashion, he sings about his anxiety and his corruption when it comes to addiction. The song leaked online in late 2019, but was later released by Juice’s label, Grade A Productions, on April 24, 2020, four months after Juice unexpectedly passed away following a seizure at Chicago’s Midway Airport. Even before the leak, Juice and his team had previewed the song several times on Instagram Live, with Juice teasing and titling the song in the summer of 2019. One day prior the release, Juice’s fiancé posted on Twitter explaining what the song meant to her.

annotations_with_timestamps.annotation: Juice WRLD uses drowning as an analogy in relation to his problems in the unreleased song, “In a Minute’s” yet to be released. He has discussed relapsing, which he has discussed on multiple songs in his discography, including the aptly-titled track “Relapse” in his upcoming album. Juice's battle ended when he died due to an accidental overdose in December 2019.

In the Bible, Hell is a place where people who sin, and don’t repent, go to when they die. This place is for eternal suffering and is illustrated as horrible to be in with flames, demons, and people agonizing all around. Juice would then mean he wants them to stop doing anything that might try to block them from staying together.

Juice spoke about having “red eyes” before in his 2018 track, “Lean Wit Me’s” “Blood moons” are the phases that happen when the moon enters its lunar eclipse. These moons usually happen twice every three years, making it a rare event for many watchers. Unfortunately, a lot of Juice's lyrical content revolves around drug abuse, notably his usage of Percocet and codeine.

Juice WRLD’s lyrics often refer to demons and devils in his music. His most popular song, “Lucid Dreams“ and “All Girls are the Same,“ may be referring to his relationship with an ex-girlfriend. The words simultaneously act as a metaphor for Juice's drug addiction. The same can be said for his tumultuous relationship with illicit medicines.

Juice anticipates a fight with his demons, whom he mentions on the aptly named “Fighting Demons,” which released posthumously in July 2020. Juice has used demons before to symbolize his emotional lows, notably on songs like “Demonz” from 2019’s Death Race for Love where featured singer Brent Faiyaz sings: "Demonz"

Juice references lean, a concoction usually made with a mixture of codeine/promethazine cough syrup, a soft drink, and ice. The cover art for the song is a cartoonish caricature of Juice WRLD wearing an all white suit with a backdrop of what is presumably heaven. “Codeine runneth over” alludes to Psalm 23:5, a Bible verse that reads: Thou preparest a table before me in the presence of mine enemies: thou anointest my head with oil;.
